Implementation of TEP 112 (Microcontroller Power Management) for the Atmega128.
TransformCounterC decreases precision and/or widens an Counter.
RealMain implements the TinyOS boot sequence, as documented in TEP 107.
The TinyOS scheduler.
The virtualized active message send abstraction.
The virtualized active message send abstraction.
Internal AM component that fills in needed packet fields for the AMSend -> Send transformation.
The fair-share send queue for AM radio communication.
An AM send queue that provides a Service Instance pattern for formatted packets and calls an underlying AMSend in a round-robin fashion.
Component that stores the node's active message address and group ID.

Please refer to TEP 108 for more information about this component and its intended use.

This component provides the Resource, ArbiterInfo, and Resource Controller interfaces and uses the ResourceConfigure interface as described in TEP 108.
documentation.long:
Please refer to TEP 108 for more information about this component and its intended use.

This component provides the Resource, ArbiterInfo, and Resource Controller interfaces and uses the ResourceConfigure interface as described in TEP 108. It provides arbitration to a shared resource in an FCFS fashion. An array is used to keep track of which users have put in requests for the resource. Upon the release of the resource by one of these users, the array is checked and the next user (in FCFS order) that has a pending request will ge granted control of the resource. If there are no pending requests, then the resource becomes idle and any user can put in a request and immediately receive access to the Resource. @param resourceName -- The name of the Resource being shared @author Kevin Klues (klues@tkn.tu-berlin.de) @author Philip Levis

documentation.short:
Please refer to TEP 108 for more information about this component and its intended use.

This component provides the Resource, ArbiterInfo, and ResourceRequested interfaces and uses the ResourceConfigure interface as described in TEP 108.
documentation.long:
Please refer to TEP 108 for more information about this component and its intended use.

This component provides the Resource, ArbiterInfo, and ResourceRequested interfaces and uses the ResourceConfigure interface as described in TEP 108. It provides arbitration to a shared resource. An queue is used to keep track of which users have put in requests for the resource. Upon the release of the resource by one of these users, the queue is checked and the next user that has a pending request will ge granted control of the resource. If there are no pending requests, then the resource becomes idle and any user can put in a request and immediately receive access to the Resource. @author Kevin Klues (klues@tkn.tu-berlin.de) @author Philip Levis

documentation.short: The standard TinyOS random number generator.
This code is a fast implementation of the Park-Miller Minimal Standard Generator for pseudo-random numbers.
documentation.long:
This code is a fast implementation of the Park-Miller Minimal Standard Generator for pseudo-random numbers. It uses the 32 bit multiplicative linear congruential generator,
S' = (A x S) mod (2^31 - 1)
for A = 16807.
@author Barbara Hohlt @date March 1 2005

documentation.short: CounterToLocalTimeC converts a 32-bit LocalTime to a Counter.
CounterToLocalTimeC converts a 32-bit LocalTime to a Counter.
The virtualized AM reception abstraction.
The virtualized millisecond timer abstraction.
TransformAlarmC decreases precision and/or widens an Alarm.
AlarmToTimerC converts a 32-bit Alarm to a Timer.
VirtualizeTimerC uses a single Timer to create up to 255 virtual timers.
Generic component to expose a full 8-bit port of GPIO pins.
documentation.long:

@author Martin Turon <mturon@xbow.com>

This component provides the Resource, ArbiterInfo, and Resource Controller interfaces and uses the ResourceConfigure interface as described in TEP 108. It provides arbitration to a shared resource in an FCFS fashion. An array is used to keep track of which users have put in requests for the resource. Upon the release of the resource by one of these users, the array is checked and the next user (in FCFS order) that has a pending request will ge granted control of the resource. If there are no pending requests, then the resource becomes idle and any user can put in a request and immediately receive access to the Resource. @param resourceName -- The name of the Resource being shared @author Kevin Klues (klues@tkn.tu-berlin.de) @author Philip Levis

documentation.short:
Please refer to TEP 108 for more information about this component and its intended use.

documentation.long:

This component provides the Resource, ArbiterInfo, and ResourceRequested interfaces and uses the ResourceConfigure interface as described in TEP 108. It provides arbitration to a shared resource. An queue is used to keep track of which users have put in requests for the resource. Upon the release of the resource by one of these users, the queue is checked and the next user that has a pending request will ge granted control of the resource. If there are no pending requests, then the resource becomes idle and any user can put in a request and immediately receive access to the Resource. @author Kevin Klues (klues@tkn.tu-berlin.de) @author Philip Levis

documentation.short: CounterToLocalTimeC converts a 32-bit LocalTime to a Counter.
The virtualized AM reception abstraction.
The virtualized millisecond timer abstraction.
TransformAlarmC decreases precision and/or widens an Alarm.
AlarmToTimerC converts a 32-bit Alarm to a Timer.
VirtualizeTimerC uses a single Timer to create up to 255 virtual timers.
Initialize this component.
Interface that notifies components when TinyOS has booted (initialized all of its components), as discussed in TEP 107.
Signaled when the system has booted successfully.
This interface provides functions to compute ATmega128 configuration values that are clock-rate dependent.
documentation.long:
This interface provides functions to compute ATmega128 configuration values that are clock-rate dependent. These include:
  • the ADC prescaler value necessary for full precision
  • values for the UBRR registers to achieve a specific baud rate
  • any adjustment necessary to values passed to some platform-provided AlarmMicroXXC components to get more accurate timing
  • the number of cycles per 1/32768s (a typical implementation of this interface will measure this value at boot time and use it to compute the values above)
@author David Gay

documentation.short: Return the value to use for the baudrate register to achieve a particular baud rate.
documentation.long: Return the value to use for the baudrate register to achieve a particular baud rate. Assumes U2X=1 (the USART is being run at double speed).

documentation.short: Return CPU cycles per 1/32768s.
documentation.long: Return CPU cycles per 1/32768s. @return CPU cycles.

documentation.short: Convert n microseconds into a value suitable for use with AlarmMicro32C Alarms.
Convert values used by AlarmMicro32C Alarms into actual microseconds.
Return the smallest ADC prescaler value which guaranteers full ADC precision.

documentation.long: @author Jonathan Hui <jhui@archedrock.com> @version $Revision: 1.5 $ $Date: 2008-06-04 03:00:35 $

documentation.short: Send a single uart byte.
Receive a single uart byte.

documentation.long: @author Jonathan Hui <jhui@archedrock.com> @version $Revision: 1.5 $ $Date: 2008-06-04 03:00:35 $

documentation.short: Begin transmission of a UART stream.
Signals the receipt of a byte.
documentation.long:
Signals the receipt of a byte.
@param byte The byte received.

documentation.short: Begin reception of a UART stream.
Enable the receive byte interrupt.
Signal completion of receiving a stream.
Disable the receive byte interrupt.
documentation.long:
Disable the receive byte interrupt.
@return SUCCESS if interrupt was disabled, FAIL otherwise.

documentation.short: Signal completion of sending a stream.
Post this task to the TinyOS scheduler.
documentation.long:
Post this task to the TinyOS scheduler. At some later time, depending on the scheduling policy, the scheduler will signal the <tt>run()</tt> event.
@return SUCCESS if task was successfuly posted; the semantics of a non-SUCCESS return value depend on the implementation of this interface (the class of task).

documentation.short: Event from the scheduler to run this task.
documentation.long: Event from the scheduler to run this task. Following the TinyOS concurrency model, the codes invoked from <tt>run()</tt> signals execute atomically with respect to one another, but can be preempted by async commands/events.

documentation.short: A Counter counts time in some units and in some width, signaling overflow.
documentation.long:
A Counter counts time in some units and in some width, signaling overflow.

A Counter is parameterised by its "precision" (milliseconds, microseconds, etc), identified by a type. This prevents, e.g., unintentionally mixing components expecting milliseconds with those expecting microseconds as those interfaces have a different type.

A Counter's second parameter is its "width", i.e., the number of bits used to represent time values. Width is indicated by including the appropriate size integer type as a Counter parameter.

See TEP102 for more details. @param precision_tag A type indicating the precision of this Counter. @param size_type An integer type representing time values for this Counter. @author Cory Sharp

documentation.short: Return counter value.
Cancel a pending overflow interrupt.
documentation.long: Cancel a pending overflow interrupt.

documentation.short: Return TRUE if an overflow event will occur after the outermost atomic block is exits.
Signals that the current time has overflowed.
documentation.long: Signals that the current time has overflowed. That is, the current time has wrapped around from its maximum value to zero.

documentation.short: Constants for manipulating LEDs.
Turn off LED 0.
documentation.long: Turn off LED 0. The color of this LED depends on the platform.

documentation.short: Toggle LED 0; if it was off, turn it on, if was on, turn it off.
documentation.long: Toggle LED 0; if it was off, turn it on, if was on, turn it off. The color of this LED depends on the platform.

documentation.short: Turn on LED 1.
documentation.long: Turn on LED 1. The color of this LED depends on the platform.

documentation.short: Toggle LED 1; if it was off, turn it on, if was on, turn it off.
documentation.long: Toggle LED 1; if it was off, turn it on, if was on, turn it off. The color of this LED depends on the platform.

documentation.short: Toggle LED 2; if it was off, turn it on, if was on, turn it off.
documentation.long: Toggle LED 2; if it was off, turn it on, if was on, turn it off. The color of this LED depends on the platform.

documentation.short: Get the current LED settings as a bitmask.
documentation.long:
Get the current LED settings as a bitmask. Each bit corresponds to whether an LED is on; bit 0 is LED 0, bit 1 is LED 1, etc. You can also use the enums LEDS_LED0, LEDS_LED1. For example, this expression will determine whether LED 2 is on: 
 (call Leds.get() & LEDS_LED2)
This command supports up to 8 LEDs; if a platform has fewer, then those LEDs should always be off (their bit is zero). Also see set(). @return a bitmask describing which LEDs are on and which are off

documentation.short: Turn off LED 1.
documentation.long: Turn off LED 1. The color of this LED depends on the platform.

documentation.short: Set the current LED configuration using a bitmask.
documentation.long:
Set the current LED configuration using a bitmask. Each bit corresponds to whether an LED is on; bit 0 is LED 0, bit 1 is LED 1, etc. You can also use the enums LEDS_LED0, LEDS_LED1. For example, this statement will configure the LEDs so LED 0 and LED 2 are on: 
 call Leds.set(LEDS_LED0 | LEDS_LED2);
This statement will turn LED 1 on if it was not already: 
call Leds.set(call Leds.get() | LEDS_LED1);
@param val a bitmask describing the on/off settings of the LEDs

documentation.short: Turn on LED 0.
documentation.long: Turn on LED 0. The color of this LED depends on the platform.

documentation.short: Turn on LED 2.
documentation.long: Turn on LED 2. The color of this LED depends on the platform.

documentation.short: Turn off LED 2.
documentation.long: Turn off LED 2. The color of this LED depends on the platform.

documentation.short: Interface to allow high-level components to set a lower bound for a microcontroller's low power state.
Called when computing the low power state, in order to allow a high-level component to institute a lower bound.
documentation.long:
Called when computing the low power state, in order to allow a high-level component to institute a lower bound. Because this command originates deep within the basic TinyOS scheduling mechanisms, it should be used very sparingly. Refer to TEP 112 for details.
@return the lowest power state the system can enter to meet the requirements of this component
@author Joe Polastre

documentation.short: Interface to instruct the MCU to enter a low power state.
Called by the scheduler to put the MCU to sleep.
documentation.long: Called by the scheduler to put the MCU to sleep. *

documentation.short: Interface to instruct TinyOS that the low-power state of the MCU may have changed.
Called by any component to tell TinyOS that the MCU low power state may have changed.
documentation.long: Called by any component to tell TinyOS that the MCU low power state may have changed. Generally, this should be called whenever a peripheral/timer is started/stopped.

documentation.short: The interface to a TinyOS task scheduler.
Initialize the scheduler.
documentation.long: Initialize the scheduler.

documentation.short: Enter an infinite task-running loop.
documentation.long: Enter an infinite task-running loop. Put the MCU into a low power state when the processor is idle (task queue empty, waiting for interrupts). This call never returns.

documentation.short: Run the next task if one is waiting, otherwise return immediately.

Please refer to TEP 115 for more information about this interface and its intended use.

This is the split-phase counterpart to the StdContol interface.
documentation.long:
Please refer to TEP 115 for more information about this interface and its intended use.

This is the split-phase counterpart to the StdContol interface. It should be used for switching between the on and off power states of the component providing it. For each start() or stop() command, if the command returns SUCCESS, then a corresponding startDone() or stopDone() event must be signalled. @author Joe Polastre @author Kevin Klues (klueska@cs.wustl.edu)

documentation.short: Notify caller that the component has been started and is ready to receive other commands.
documentation.long: Notify caller that the component has been started and is ready to receive other commands. @param error -- SUCCESS if the component was successfully turned on, FAIL otherwise

documentation.short: Notify caller that the component has been stopped.
Start this component and all of its subcomponents.
documentation.long:
Start this component and all of its subcomponents. Return values of SUCCESS will always result in a startDone() event being signalled. @return SUCCESS if the device is already in the process of starting or the device was off and the device is now ready to turn on. After receiving this return value, you should expect a startDone event in the near future.
EBUSY if the component is in the middle of powering down i.e. a stop() command has been called, and a stopDone() event is pending
EALREADY if the device is already on
FAIL Otherwise

documentation.short: Start this component and all of its subcomponents.
documentation.long:
Start this component and all of its subcomponents. Return values of SUCCESS will always result in a startDone() event being signalled. @return SUCCESS if the device is already in the process of stopping or the device was on and the device is now ready to turn off. After receiving this return value, you should expect a stopDone event in the near future.
EBUSY if the component is in the middle of powering up i.e. a start() command has been called, and a startDone() event is pending
EALREADY if the device is already off
FAIL Otherwise

documentation.short: Send a packet with a data payload of <tt>len</tt> to address <tt>addr</tt>.
documentation.long:
Send a packet with a data payload of <tt>len</tt> to address <tt>addr</tt>. To determine the maximum available size, use the Packet interface of the component providing AMSend. If send returns SUCCESS, then the component will signal the sendDone event in the future; if send returns an error, it will not signal the event. Note that a component may accept a send request which it later finds it cannot satisfy; in this case, it will signal sendDone with error code.
@param addr address to which to send the packet @param 'message_t* ONE msg' the packet @param len the length of the data in the packet payload @return SUCCESS if the request to send succeeded and a sendDone will be signaled later, EBUSY if the abstraction cannot send now but will be able to later, or FAIL if the communication layer is not in a state that can send (e.g., off). @see sendDone

documentation.short: Return a pointer to a protocol's payload region in a packet.
Return the maximum payload length that this communication layer can provide.
documentation.long:
Return the maximum payload length that this communication layer can provide. This command behaves identically to <tt>Packet.maxPayloadLength</tt> and is included in this interface as a convenience.
@return the maximum payload length

documentation.short: Cancel a requested transmission.
documentation.long:
Cancel a requested transmission. Returns SUCCESS if the transmission was canceled properly (not sent in its entirety). Note that the component may not know if the send was successfully canceled, if the radio is handling much of the logic; in this case, a component should be conservative and return an appropriate error code. A successful call to cancel must always result in a sendFailed event, and never a sendSucceeded event.
@param 'message_t* ONE msg' the packet whose transmission should be cancelled. @return SUCCESS if the transmission was cancelled, FAIL otherwise. @see sendDone

documentation.short: Signaled in response to an accepted send request.
The basic message data type accessors.
Clear out this packet.
documentation.long: Clear out this packet. Note that this is a deep operation and total operation: calling clear() on any layer will completely clear the packet for reuse. @param 'message_t* ONE msg' the packet to clear

documentation.short: Return the length of the payload of msg.
documentation.long:
Return the length of the payload of msg. This value may be less than what maxPayloadLength() returns, if the packet is smaller than the MTU. If a communication component does not support variably sized data regions, then payloadLength() will always return the same value as maxPayloadLength().
@param 'message_t* ONE msg' the packet to examine @return the length of its current payload

documentation.short: Return a pointer to a protocol's payload region in a packet.
documentation.long:
Return a pointer to a protocol's payload region in a packet. If the caller intends to write to the payload region then the <tt>len</tt> parameter must reflect the maximum required length. If the caller (only) wants to read from the payload region, then <tt>len</tt> may be set to the value of payloadLength(). If the payload region is smaller than <tt>len</tt> this command returns NULL. The offset where the payload region starts within a packet is fixed, i.e. for a given <tt>msg</tt> this command will always return the same pointer or NULL.
@param 'message_t* ONE msg' the packet @param len the length of payload required @return 'void* COUNT_NOK(len)' a pointer to the packet's data payload for this layer or NULL if <tt>len</tt> is too big

documentation.short: Return the maximum payload length that this communication layer can provide.
documentation.long:
Return the maximum payload length that this communication layer can provide. Note that, depending on protocol fields, a given request to send a packet may not be able to send the maximum payload length (e.g., if there are variable length fields). Protocols may provide specialized interfaces for these circumstances.
@return the maximum size payload allowed by this layer

documentation.short: Set the length field of the packet.
documentation.long:
Set the length field of the packet. This value is not checked for validity (e.g., if it is larger than the maximum payload size). This command is not used when sending packets, as calls to send include a length parameter. Rather, it is used by components, such as queues, that need to buffer requests to send. This command allows the component to store the length specified in the request and later recover it when actually sending.
@param 'message_t* ONE msg' the packet @param len the value to set its length field to

documentation.short: Receive a packet buffer, returning a buffer for the signaling component to use for the next reception.
documentation.long: Receive a packet buffer, returning a buffer for the signaling component to use for the next reception. The return value can be the same as msg, as long as the handling component copies out the data it needs. Note that misuse of this interface is one of the most common bugs in TinyOS code. For example, if a component both calls a send on the passed message and returns it, then it is possible the buffer will be reused before the send occurs, overwriting the component's data. This would cause the mote to possibly instead send a packet it most recently received. @param 'message_t* ONE msg' the receied packet @param 'void* COUNT(len) payload' a pointer to the packet's payload @param len the length of the data region pointed to by payload @return 'message_t* ONE' a packet buffer for the stack to use for the next received packet.

documentation.short: A Timer is TinyOS's general purpose timing interface.
documentation.long:
A Timer is TinyOS's general purpose timing interface. For more precise timing, you may wish to use a (platform-specific) component offering an Alarm interface.

A Timer is parameterised by its "precision" (milliseconds, microseconds, etc), identified by a type. This prevents, e.g., unintentionally mixing components expecting milliseconds with those expecting microseconds as those interfaces have a different type.

See TEP102 for more details. @param precision_tag A type indicating the precision of this Alarm. @author Cory Sharp

documentation.short: Return the current time.
documentation.long: Return the current time. @return Current time.

documentation.short: Signaled when the timer expires (one-shot) or repeats (periodic).
documentation.long: Signaled when the timer expires (one-shot) or repeats (periodic).

documentation.short: Set a periodic timer to repeat every dt time units.
documentation.long:
Set a periodic timer to repeat every dt time units. Replaces any current timer settings. The fired will be signaled every dt units (first event at t0+dt units). Periodic timers set in the past will get a bunch of events in succession, until the timer "catches up".

Because the current time may wrap around, it is possible to use values of t0 greater than the getNow's result. These values represent times in the past, i.e., the time at which getNow() would last of returned that value. @param t0 Base time for timer. @param dt Time until the timer fires.

documentation.short: Check if this is a one-shot timer.
documentation.long: Check if this is a one-shot timer. @return TRUE for one-shot timers, FALSE for periodic timers.

documentation.short: Return the delay or period for the previously started timer.
Return the time anchor for the previously started timer or the time of the previous event for periodic timers.
documentation.long: Return the time anchor for the previously started timer or the time of the previous event for periodic timers. The next fired event will occur at gett0() + getdt(). @return Timer's base time.

documentation.short: Check if timer is running.
Set a periodic timer to repeat every dt time units.
documentation.long: Set a periodic timer to repeat every dt time units. Replaces any current timer settings. Equivalent to startPeriodicAt(getNow(), dt). The fired will be signaled every dt units (first event in dt units). @param dt Time until the timer fires.

documentation.short: Set a single-short timer to time t0+dt.
documentation.long:
Set a single-short timer to time t0+dt. Replaces any current timer settings. The fired will be signaled when the timer expires. Timers set in the past will fire "soon".

Because the current time may wrap around, it is possible to use values of t0 greater than the getNow's result. These values represent times in the past, i.e., the time at which getNow() would last of returned that value. @param t0 Base time for timer. @param dt Time until the timer fires.

documentation.short: Set a single-short timer to some time units in the future.
documentation.long: Set a single-short timer to some time units in the future. Replaces any current timer settings. Equivalent to startOneShotAt(getNow(), dt). The fired will be signaled when the timer expires. @param dt Time until the timer fires.

documentation.short: Cancel a timer.
documentation.long: Cancel a timer.

documentation.short: The Active Message accessors, which provide the AM local address and functionality for querying packets.
Get the AM group of the AM packet.
documentation.long:
Get the AM group of the AM packet. The AM group is a logical identifier that distinguishes sets of nodes which may share a physical communication medium but wish to not communicate. The AM group logically separates the sets of nodes. When a node sends a packet, it fills in its AM group, and typically nodes only receive packets whose AM group field matches their own.
@param 'message_t* ONE amsg' the packet @return the AM group of this packet

documentation.short: Return the AM address of the source of the AM packet.
Return the node's active message address associated with this AM stack.
documentation.long: Return the node's active message address associated with this AM stack. @return The address

documentation.short: Return the AM address of the destination of the AM packet.
Set the AM address of the source field of the AM packet.
documentation.long:
Set the AM address of the source field of the AM packet. As the AM address is set as part of sending with the AMSend interface, this command is not used for sending packets. Rather, it is used when a component, such as a queue, needs to buffer a request to send. The component can save the source address and then recover it when actually sending. As an AM layer generally sets the source address to be the local address, this interface is not commonly used except when a system is bypassing the AM layer (e.g., a protocol bridge). If <tt>amsg</tt> is not an AM packet, the results of this command are undefined.
@param 'message_t* ONE amsg' the packet @param addr the address

documentation.short: Set the AM address of the destination field of the AM packet.
documentation.long:
Set the AM address of the destination field of the AM packet. As the AM address is set as part of sending with the AMSend interface, this command is not used for sending packets. Rather, it is used when a component, such as a queue, needs to buffer a request to send. The component can save the destination address and then recover it when actually sending. If <tt>amsg</tt> is not an AM packet, the results of this command are undefined.
@param 'message_t* ONE amsg' the packet @param addr the address

documentation.short: Return the AM type of the AM packet.
Set the AM type of the AM packet.
documentation.long:
Set the AM type of the AM packet. As the AM type is set as part of sending with the AMSend interface, this command is not used for sending packets. Instead, it is used when a component, such as a queue, needs to buffer a request to send. The component can save the AM type in the packet then recover it when actually sending. If <tt>amsg</tt> is not an AM packet, the results of this command are undefined.
@param 'message_t* ONE amsg' the packet @param t the AM type

documentation.short: Return whether <tt>amsg</tt> is destined for this mote.
documentation.long:
Return whether <tt>amsg</tt> is destined for this mote. This is partially a shortcut for testing whether the return value of <tt>destination</tt> and <tt>address</tt> are the same. It may, however, include additional logic. For example, there may be an AM broadcast address: <tt>destination</tt> will return the broadcast address, but <tt>address</tt> will still be the mote's local address. If <tt>amsg</tt> is not an AM packet, the results of this command are undefined.
@param 'message_t* ONE amsg' the packet @return whether the packet is addressed to this AM stack

documentation.short: Set the AM group field of a packet.
Provides the current AM group of this communication interface.
documentation.long:
Provides the current AM group of this communication interface.
@return The AM group.

documentation.short: This interface allows a component to enable or disable acknowledgments on a per-packet basis.
Tell a protocol that when it sends this packet, it should use synchronous acknowledgments.
documentation.long:
Tell a protocol that when it sends this packet, it should use synchronous acknowledgments. The acknowledgment is synchronous as the caller can check whether the ack was received through the wasAcked() command as soon as a send operation completes.
@param 'message_t* ONE msg' - A message which should be acknowledged when transmitted. @return SUCCESS if acknowledgements are enabled, EBUSY if the communication layer cannot enable them at this time, FAIL if it does not support them.

documentation.short: Tell a protocol that when it sends this packet, it should not use synchronous acknowledgments.
Tell a caller whether or not a transmitted packet was acknowledged.
documentation.long:
Tell a caller whether or not a transmitted packet was acknowledged. If acknowledgments on the packet had been disabled through noAck(), then the return value is undefined. If a packet layer does not support acknowledgements, this command must return always return FALSE.
@param 'message_t* ONE msg' - A transmitted message. @return Whether the packet was acknowledged.

documentation.short: Send a packet with a data payload of <tt>len</tt>.
documentation.long:
Send a packet with a data payload of <tt>len</tt>. To determine the maximum available size, use the Packet interface of the component providing Send. If send returns SUCCESS, then the component will signal the sendDone event in the future; if send returns an error, it will not signal sendDone. Note that a component may accept a send request which it later finds it cannot satisfy; in this case, it will signal sendDone with an appropriate error code.
@param 'message_t* ONE msg' the packet to send @param len the length of the packet payload @return SUCCESS if the request was accepted and will issue a sendDone event, EBUSY if the component cannot accept the request now but will be able to later, FAIL if the stack is in a state that cannot accept requests (e.g., it's off).

documentation.short: Return a pointer to a protocol's payload region in a packet which at least a certain length.
documentation.long:
Return a pointer to a protocol's payload region in a packet which at least a certain length. If the payload region is smaller than the len parameter, then getPayload returns NULL. This command behaves identicallt to <tt>Packet.getPayload</tt> and is included in this interface as a convenience.
@param 'message_t* ONE msg' the packet @return 'void* COUNT_NOK(len)' a pointer to the packet's payload

documentation.short: Return the maximum payload length that this communication layer can provide.
documentation.long:
Return the maximum payload length that this communication layer can provide. This command behaves identically to <tt>Packet.maxPayloadLength</tt> and is included in this interface as a convenience.
@return the maximum payload length

documentation.short: Cancel a requested transmission.
documentation.long:
Cancel a requested transmission. Returns SUCCESS if the transmission was cancelled properly (not sent in its entirety). Note that the component may not know if the send was successfully cancelled, if the radio is handling much of the logic; in this case, a component should be conservative and return an appropriate error code.
@param 'message_t* ONE msg' the packet whose transmission should be cancelled @return SUCCESS if the packet was successfully cancelled, FAIL otherwise

documentation.short: Signaled in response to an accepted send request.
The radio stack notifies the entire system that it is about to send a packet.
The system is about to send this message.
Low Power Listening interface
Configure this outgoing message so it can be transmitted to a neighbor mote with the specified wakeup interval.

documentation.long: @param 'message_t* ONE msg' @return the destination node's wakeup interval configured in this message
@return the local node's wakeup interval, in [ms]

documentation.short: Set this this node's radio wakeup interval, in milliseconds.

documentation.long:
@param 'message_t *ONE msg' Message to get timestamp from.
Return the time stamp for the given message. Please check with the isValid command if this value can be relied upon. If this command is called after transmission, then the transmit time of the packet is returned (the time when the frame synchronization byte was transmitted). If this command is called after the message is received, the tne receive time of the message is returned. It is recommended that the timestamp command be called only from the receive or sendDone event handler.

@param 'message_t *ONE msg' Message to modify.
Sets the isValid flag to FALSE.

@param 'message_t *ONE msg' Message to examine.
Returns TRUE if the time stamp of the message is valid. Under special circumstances the radio chip might not be able to correctly assign a precise time value to an incoming packet (e.g. under very heavy traffic multiple interrupts can occur before they could be serviced, and even if capture registers are used, it is not possible to get the time stamp for the first or last unserviced event), in which case the time stamp value should not be used. It is recommended that the isValid command be called from the receive or sendDone event handler.

documentation.short: This event is signaled exactly once for each sucessfully posted state setChannel command when it is completed.
documentation.long: This event is signaled exactly once for each sucessfully posted state setChannel command when it is completed.

documentation.short: Sets the current channel.
documentation.long: Sets the current channel. Returns EBUSY if the stack is unable to change the channel this time (some other operation is in progress), EALREADY if the selected channel is already set, SUCCESS otherwise.

documentation.short: Returns the currently selected channel.
documentation.long: Returns the currently selected channel.

documentation.short: Clears the isSet flag.
documentation.long: Clears the isSet flag.

documentation.short: Returns the stored value of this field in the message.
documentation.long: Returns the stored value of this field in the message. If the value is not set, then the returned value is undefined.

documentation.short: Returns TRUE if the value is set for this message.
documentation.long: Returns TRUE if the value is set for this message.

documentation.short: Sets the isSet false to TRUE and the time stamp value to the specified value.
documentation.long: Sets the isSet false to TRUE and the time stamp value to the specified value.

documentation.short: A LocalTime interface counts time in some units.
documentation.long:
A LocalTime interface counts time in some units. If you need to detect time overflow, you should use a component offering the Counter interface.

The LocalTime interface is parameterised by its "precision" (milliseconds, microseconds, etc), identified by a type. This prevents, e.g., unintentionally mixing components expecting milliseconds with those expecting microseconds as those interfaces have a different type.

See TEP102 for more details. @param precision_tag A type indicating the precision of this Counter. @author Cory Sharp

documentation.short: Return current time.

Please refer to TEP 108 for more information about this interface and its intended use.

The Resource interface can be used to gain access to shared resources.
Release a shared resource you previously acquired.
documentation.long:
Release a shared resource you previously acquired. @return SUCCESS The resource has been released
FAIL You tried to release but you are not the owner of the resource @note This command should never be called between putting in a request and waiting for a granted event. Doing so will result in a potential race condition. There are ways to guarantee that no race will occur, but they are clumsy and overly complicated. Since it doesn't logically make since to be calling release before receiving a granted event, we have opted to keep thing simple and warn you about the potential race.

documentation.short: Request immediate access to a shared resource.
documentation.long:
Request immediate access to a shared resource. You must call release() when you are done with it. @return SUCCESS When a request has been accepted.
FAIL The request cannot be fulfilled

documentation.short: Request access to a shared resource.
documentation.long:
Request access to a shared resource. You must call release() when you are done with it. @return SUCCESS When a request has been accepted. The granted() event will be signaled once you have control of the resource.
EBUSY You have already requested this resource and a granted event is pending

documentation.short: You are now in control of the resource.
documentation.long: You are now in control of the resource.

documentation.short: Check if the user of this interface is the current owner of the Resource
documentation.long:
Check if the user of this interface is the current owner of the Resource @return TRUE It is the owner
FALSE It is not the owner

documentation.short: Send a packet with a data payload of <tt>len</tt> to address <tt>addr</tt>.
documentation.long:
Send a packet with a data payload of <tt>len</tt> to address <tt>addr</tt>. To determine the maximum available size, use the Packet interface of the component providing AMSend. If send returns SUCCESS, then the component will signal the sendDone event in the future; if send returns an error, it will not signal the event. Note that a component may accept a send request which it later finds it cannot satisfy; in this case, it will signal sendDone with error code.
@param addr address to which to send the packet @param msg the packet @param len the length of the data in the packet payload @return SUCCESS if the request to send succeeded and a sendDone will be signaled later, EBUSY if the abstraction cannot send now but will be able to later, or FAIL if the communication layer is not in a state that can send (e.g., off). @see sendDone

documentation.short: Return a pointer to a protocol's payload region in a packet.
Return the maximum payload length that this communication layer can provide.
documentation.long:
Return the maximum payload length that this communication layer can provide. This command behaves identically to <tt>Packet.maxPayloadLength</tt> and is included in this interface as a convenience.
@return the maximum payload length

documentation.short: Cancel a requested transmission.
documentation.long:
Cancel a requested transmission. Returns SUCCESS if the transmission was canceled properly (not sent in its entirety). Note that the component may not know if the send was successfully canceled, if the radio is handling much of the logic; in this case, a component should be conservative and return an appropriate error code. A successful call to cancel must always result in a sendFailed event, and never a sendSucceeded event.
@param msg the packet whose transmission should be cancelled. @return SUCCESS if the transmission was cancelled, FAIL otherwise. @see sendDone

documentation.short: Signaled in response to an accepted send request.
We need to put something here, but this is not going to get called
Returns the number of bytes in this message.
documentation.long: Returns the number of bytes in this message.

documentation.short: Same as AMPacket.group *
Check if the packet is properly formatted, and if the user forgot to call Packet.clear then format it properly.
documentation.long: Check if the packet is properly formatted, and if the user forgot to call Packet.clear then format it properly. Return SUCCESS if the frame is now properly set up, or FAIL of the send operation should be aborted.

documentation.short: Same as AMPacket.source *
Same as AMPacket.destination *
Same as AMPacket.setSource *
Same as AMPacket.setDestination *
Same as AMPacket.setGroup *
This command should return the approximate transmit delay between setting an alarm, waiting for the fire event, calling send and obtaining the timestamp for the transmitted message.
documentation.long: This command should return the approximate transmit delay between setting an alarm, waiting for the fire event, calling send and obtaining the timestamp for the transmitted message.

documentation.short: Must return a binary exponent so that the collision avoidance layer can assign slots in the range of [0, 1 << exponent) of size collision window.
documentation.long: Must return a binary exponent so that the collision avoidance layer can assign slots in the range of [0, 1 << exponent) of size collision window.

documentation.short: Returns the size of the collision window for this received message.
documentation.long: Returns the size of the collision window for this received message.

documentation.short: This command must return the time when the message was transmitted.
documentation.long: This command must return the time when the message was transmitted.

documentation.short: Returns the start of the collision window for this received message, so transmit times in this range would be considered possible collisions.
documentation.long: Returns the start of the collision window for this received message, so transmit times in this range would be considered possible collisions.

documentation.short: This command is called when the message is transmitted to check if it needs software clear channel assesment.
documentation.long: This command is called when the message is transmitted to check if it needs software clear channel assesment.

documentation.short: This command is called when a sent packet did not receive an acknowledgement.
documentation.long: This command is called when a sent packet did not receive an acknowledgement.

documentation.short: Creates an acknowledgement packet for the given data packet.
documentation.long: Creates an acknowledgement packet for the given data packet.

documentation.short: Returns TRUE if the layer should wait for a software acknowledgement to be received after this packet was transmitted.
documentation.long: Returns TRUE if the layer should wait for a software acknowledgement to be received after this packet was transmitted.

documentation.short: Returns TRUE if the received packet is an acknowledgement packet.
documentation.long: Returns TRUE if the received packet is an acknowledgement packet. The AckedSend layer will filter out all received acknowledgement packets and uses only the matching one for the acknowledgement.

documentation.short: Returns TRUE if the acknowledgement packet corresponds to the data packet.
documentation.long: Returns TRUE if the acknowledgement packet corresponds to the data packet. The acknowledgement packect was already verified to be a valid acknowledgement packet via the isAckPacket command.

documentation.short: Returns the acknowledgement timeout (in the radio clock units), in which a sent packet must be acknowledged.
documentation.long: Returns the acknowledgement timeout (in the radio clock units), in which a sent packet must be acknowledged.

documentation.short: Sets the flag in the message indicating to the receiver whether the message should be acknowledged.
documentation.long: Sets the flag in the message indicating to the receiver whether the message should be acknowledged.

documentation.short: Returns TRUE if the received packet needs software acknowledgements to be sent back to the sender.
documentation.long: Returns TRUE if the received packet needs software acknowledgements to be sent back to the sender.

documentation.short: This interface encapsulates IEEE 802.15.4 intrapan data frames with 16-bit destination pan, source and destination addresses.
documentation.long: This interface encapsulates IEEE 802.15.4 intrapan data frames with 16-bit destination pan, source and destination addresses. It also supports 6LowPan interoperability mode, and acknowledgement frames. Note, that this interface does not support the CRC-16 value, which should be verified before the data can be trusted.

documentation.short: returns the destination PAN id, values <= 255 are tinyos groups, valid only for data frames
Returns the data sequence number
Sets the frame control field.
documentation.long: Sets the frame control field. This method should not be used, createDataFrame and createAckFrame should be used instead.

documentation.short: Returns TRUE if the message is an acknowledgement frame supported by this interface (based on the value of the FCF).
documentation.long: Returns TRUE if the message is an acknowledgement frame supported by this interface (based on the value of the FCF).

documentation.short: Sets the source address, valid only for data frames
Sets the FCF to create a data frame supported by this interface.
documentation.long: Sets the FCF to create a data frame supported by this interface. You may call setAckRequired and setFramePending commands after this.

documentation.short: Sets the data sequence number
Creates an acknowledgement packet for the given data packet.
documentation.long: Creates an acknowledgement packet for the given data packet. This also sets the DSN value. The data message must be a data frame, the ack message will be overwritten.

documentation.short: Returns the source address, valid only for data frames
Returns TRUE if the message is a data frame supported by this interface (based on the value of the FCF).
documentation.long: Returns TRUE if the message is a data frame supported by this interface (based on the value of the FCF).

documentation.short: Returns TRUE if the ACK required field is set in the FCF.
documentation.long: Returns TRUE if the ACK required field is set in the FCF.

documentation.short: Returns TRUE if the acknowledgement packet corresponds to the data packet.
documentation.long: Returns TRUE if the acknowledgement packet corresponds to the data packet. The data message must be a data packet.

documentation.short: Returns the local address of the node (AM address)
Returns TRUE if the packet is a data packet, the ACK_REQ field is set and the destination address is not the broadcast address.
documentation.long: Returns TRUE if the packet is a data packet, the ACK_REQ field is set and the destination address is not the broadcast address.

documentation.short: Returns the local pan id (AM group)
Sets the destination address, valid only for data frames
Sets the FCF to create an acknowledgement frame supported by this interface.
documentation.long: Sets the FCF to create an acknowledgement frame supported by this interface. You may call setFramePending after this.

documentation.short: Sets the frame pending field in the FCF.
documentation.long: Sets the frame pending field in the FCF.

documentation.short: Sets the destination PAN id, valid only for data frames
Returns TRUE if the destionation of this message is either 0xFFFF or is the local address of the node.
documentation.long: Returns TRUE if the destionation of this message is either 0xFFFF or is the local address of the node.

documentation.short: Sets the ACK required field in the FCF, should never be set for acknowledgement frames.
documentation.long: Sets the ACK required field in the FCF, should never be set for acknowledgement frames.

documentation.short: Returns the frame control field.
documentation.long: Returns the frame control field. This method should not be used, isDataFrame and isAckFrame should be used instead.

documentation.short: Returns TRUE if the packet is a data packet, the ACK_REQ field is set and the destionation address is this node.
documentation.long: Returns TRUE if the packet is a data packet, the ACK_REQ field is set and the destionation address is this node.

documentation.short: Returns the destination address, valid only for data frames
Returns TRUE if the frame pending field is set in the FCF.
documentation.long: Returns TRUE if the frame pending field is set in the FCF.

documentation.short: Sets the sequence number of the packet.
documentation.long: Sets the sequence number of the packet.

documentation.short: This command is called when the unqiue layer detects a missing (jump in the data sequence number) or a duplicate packet.
documentation.long: This command is called when the unqiue layer detects a missing (jump in the data sequence number) or a duplicate packet.

documentation.short: Returns the sequence number of the packet.
documentation.long: Returns the sequence number of the packet.

documentation.short: Returns the sender of the packet.
documentation.long: Returns the sender of the packet.

documentation.short: Returns the amount of maximum backoff when there is congestion (the channel was busy for the first try)
Returns the initial amount of maximum backoff for this message.
documentation.long: Returns the initial amount of maximum backoff for this message.

documentation.short: Returns the minimum ticks before the message could be sent.
documentation.long: Returns the minimum ticks before the message could be sent.

documentation.short: The provided message was just received, and this command should return the time till no transmission should be initiated.
documentation.long: The provided message was just received, and this command should return the time till no transmission should be initiated.

documentation.short: Clears all metadata and sets all default values in the headers.
documentation.long: Clears all metadata and sets all default values in the headers.

documentation.short: Returns the length of the payload.
documentation.long: Returns the length of the payload. The payload starts right after the header.

documentation.short: Returns the maximum length that can be set for this message.
documentation.long: Returns the maximum length that can be set for this message.

documentation.short: Sets the length of the payload.
documentation.long: Sets the length of the payload.

documentation.short: This command returns the length of the header.
documentation.long: This command returns the length of the header. The header starts at the first byte of the message_t structure (some layers may add dummy bytes to allign the payload to the msg->data section).

documentation.short: Returns the length of the metadata section.
documentation.long: Returns the length of the metadata section. The metadata section is at the very end of the message_t structure and grows downwards.

documentation.short: Returns the maximum length of the PHY payload including the length field but not counting the FCF field.
documentation.long: Returns the maximum length of the PHY payload including the length field but not counting the FCF field.

documentation.short: Returns the length of a dummy header to align the payload properly.
documentation.long: Returns the length of a dummy header to align the payload properly.

documentation.short: Returns the length of a dummy metadata section to align the metadata section properly.
documentation.long: Returns the length of a dummy metadata section to align the metadata section properly.

documentation.short: Gets the number of bytes we should read before the RadioReceive.header event is fired.
documentation.long: Gets the number of bytes we should read before the RadioReceive.header event is fired. If the length of the packet is less than this amount, then that event is fired earlier. The header length must be at least one.

documentation.short: Returns TRUE if before sending this message we should make sure that the channel is clear via a very basic (and quick) RSSI check.
documentation.long: Returns TRUE if before sending this message we should make sure that the channel is clear via a very basic (and quick) RSSI check.

documentation.short: This event is fired when the specified timeout period expires.
documentation.long: This event is fired when the specified timeout period expires.

documentation.short: Waits till the specified timeout period expires.
documentation.long: Waits till the specified timeout period expires. The alarm must be free.

documentation.short: Cancels the running alarm.
documentation.long: Cancels the running alarm. The alarm must be pending.

documentation.short: Returns TRUE if the alarm is free and ready to be used.
documentation.long: Returns TRUE if the alarm is free and ready to be used. Once the alarm is free, it cannot become nonfree in the same tasklet block. Note, if the alarm is currently set (even if for ourselves) then it is not free.

documentation.short: Returns the current time as measured by the radio stack.
documentation.long: Returns the current time as measured by the radio stack.

documentation.short: An Alarm is a low-level interface intended for precise timing.
documentation.long:
An Alarm is a low-level interface intended for precise timing.

An Alarm is parameterised by its "precision" (milliseconds, microseconds, etc), identified by a type. This prevents, e.g., unintentionally mixing components expecting milliseconds with those expecting microseconds as those interfaces have a different type.

An Alarm's second parameter is its "width", i.e., the number of bits used to represent time values. Width is indicated by including the appropriate size integer type as an Alarm parameter.

See TEP102 for more details. @param precision_tag A type indicating the precision of this Alarm. @param size_type An integer type representing time values for this Alarm. @author Cory Sharp

documentation.short: Return the current time.
documentation.long: Return the current time. @return Current time.

documentation.short: Signaled when the alarm expires.
documentation.long: Signaled when the alarm expires.

documentation.short: Set a single-short alarm to time t0+dt.
documentation.long:
Set a single-short alarm to time t0+dt. Replaces any current alarm time. The fired will be signaled when the alarm expires. Alarms set in the past will fire "soon".

Because the current time may wrap around, it is possible to use values of t0 greater than the getNow's result. These values represent times in the past, i.e., the time at which getNow() would last of returned that value. @param t0 Base time for alarm. @param dt Alarm time as offset from t0.

documentation.short: Check if alarm is running.
documentation.long: Check if alarm is running. Note that a FALSE return does not indicate that the fired event will not be signaled (it may have already started executing, but not reached your code yet). @return TRUE if the alarm is still running.

documentation.short: Return the time the currently running alarm will fire or the time that the previously running alarm was set to fire.
Set a single-short alarm to some time units in the future.
documentation.long: Set a single-short alarm to some time units in the future. Replaces any current alarm time. Equivalent to start(getNow(), dt). The fired will be signaled when the alarm expires. @param dt Time until the alarm fires.

documentation.short: Cancel an alarm.
documentation.long: Cancel an alarm. Note that the fired event may have already been signaled (even if your code has not yet started executing).

documentation.short: This interface is useful in building state machines when the state transitions should be executed atomically but with interrupts enabled.
documentation.long: This interface is useful in building state machines when the state transitions should be executed atomically but with interrupts enabled. All state transitions should take place in the run event handler or in blocks protected by the suspend and resume commands.

documentation.short: Makes sure that the run event is called at least once more.
documentation.long: Makes sure that the run event is called at least once more. If the run event is currently not executing, then it is called immediately and this command returns only after the completion of the run event. If the run event is currently executed, then this method returns at once, and makes sure that the run event is called once more when it is finished. If this method is called from a task, then by the above rules, the run event will be called from a task as well.

documentation.short: Enters a critical section of the code and meakes sure that the run event is not called while in this section.
documentation.long: Enters a critical section of the code and meakes sure that the run event is not called while in this section. No long running computation should be called from the critical session, and in particular no user event should be fired. This call is only possible from task context, otherwise we cannot guarantee that the run event is not currently running. The suspend calls can be nested. It is very important that the same number of resume commands must be called in all control paths, e.g. be very careful with the return and break commands.

documentation.short: Leaves the critical section.
documentation.long: Leaves the critical section. This call is conly possible from task context. If there were scheduled executions of the run event, then those will be called before this command returns.

documentation.short: This method is executed atomically.
documentation.long: This method is executed atomically.

documentation.short: Starts the transmission of the given message.
documentation.long: Starts the transmission of the given message. This command must not be called while another send is in progress (so one must wait for the sendDone event). Returns EBUSY if a reception is in progress or for some other reason the request cannot be temporarily satisfied (e.g. the SPI bus access could not be acquired). In this case the send command could be retried from a task. Returns SUCCESS if the transmission could be started. In this case sendDone will be fired.

documentation.short: Cancel a requested transmission.
documentation.long: Cancel a requested transmission. Returns SUCCESS if the transmission was cancelled properly (not sent in its entirety). Note that the component may not know if the send was successfully cancelled, if the radio is handling much of the logic; in this case, a component should be conservative and return an appropriate error code.

documentation.short: Signals the completion of the send command, exactly once for each successfull send command.
documentation.long: Signals the completion of the send command, exactly once for each successfull send command. If the returned error code is SUCCESS, then the message was sent (may not have been acknowledged), otherwise the message was not transmitted over the air.

documentation.short: Signals the reception of a message, but only for those messages for which SUCCESS was returned in the header event.
documentation.long: Signals the reception of a message, but only for those messages for which SUCCESS was returned in the header event. The usual owner rules apply to the message pointers.
@author Phil Levis @author David Moss
@return the active message address of this node

documentation.short: Notification that the address or group settings changed.
documentation.long: Notification that the address or group settings changed.
@return the group address of this node

documentation.short: Set the active message address of this node

Please refer to TEP 108 for more information about this interface and its intended use.

The ResourceRequested interface can be used in conjunction with the Resource interface in order to receive events based on other users requests.
This event is signalled whenever the user of this interface currently has control of the resource, and another user requests it through the Resource.request() command.
documentation.long: This event is signalled whenever the user of this interface currently has control of the resource, and another user requests it through the Resource.request() command. You may want to consider releasing a resource based on this event

documentation.short: This event is signalled whenever the user of this interface currently has control of the resource, and another user requests it through the Resource.immediateRequest() command.
documentation.long: This event is signalled whenever the user of this interface currently has control of the resource, and another user requests it through the Resource.immediateRequest() command. You may want to consider releasing a resource based on this event

documentation.short:
Please refer to TEP 108 for more information about this interface and its intended use.

This interface is provided by a Resource arbiter in order to allow users of a shared resource to configure that resource just before being granted access to it.
documentation.long:
Please refer to TEP 108 for more information about this interface and its intended use.

This interface is provided by a Resource arbiter in order to allow users of a shared resource to configure that resource just before being granted access to it. It will always be parameterized along side a parameterized Resource interface, with the ids from one mapping directly onto the ids of the other. @author Kevin Klues (klueska@cs.wustl.edu)

documentation.short: Used to unconfigure a resource just before releasing it.
documentation.long: Used to unconfigure a resource just before releasing it. Must always be used in conjuntion with the Resource interface.

documentation.short: Used to configure a resource just before being granted access to it.
documentation.long: Used to configure a resource just before being granted access to it. Must always be used in conjuntion with the Resource interface.

documentation.short:
Please refer to TEP 108 for more information about this interface and its intended use.

The ArbiterInfo interface allows a component to query the current status of an arbiter.
documentation.long:
Please refer to TEP 108 for more information about this interface and its intended use.

The ArbiterInfo interface allows a component to query the current status of an arbiter. It must be provided by ALL arbiter implementations, and can be used for a variety of different purposes. Normally it will be used in conjunction with the Resource interface for performing run time checks on access rights to a particular shared resource. @author Kevin Klues (klueska@cs.wustl.edu)

documentation.short: Check whether a resource is currently allocated.
documentation.long:
Check whether a resource is currently allocated. @return TRUE If the resource being arbitrated is currently allocated to any of its users
FALSE Otherwise.

documentation.short: Get the id of the client currently using a resource.
A queue interface for managing client ids when performing resource arbitration.
Enqueue a client id
Check to see if the queue is empty.
Check to see if a given client id has already been enqueued and is waiting to be processed.
documentation.long:
Check to see if a given client id has already been enqueued and is waiting to be processed. @return TRUE if the client id is in the queue.
FALSE if it does not

documentation.short: Retreive the client id of the next resource in the queue.
Signals the reception of a message, but only for those messages for which SUCCESS was returned in the header event.
documentation.long: Signals the reception of a message, but only for those messages for which SUCCESS was returned in the header event. The usual owner rules apply to the message pointers.

documentation.short: This event is fired when the header is received/downloaded and the higher layers are consulted whether it needs to be downloaded and further processed.
documentation.long: This event is fired when the header is received/downloaded and the higher layers are consulted whether it needs to be downloaded and further processed. Return FALSE if the message should be discarded. In particular, the message buffer layer returns FALSE if there is no space for a new message, so this message will not get acknowledged.

documentation.short: This interface provides one bit storage for each neighbor in a very fast and conveint way (without using shifts for example).
documentation.long: This interface provides one bit storage for each neighbor in a very fast and conveint way (without using shifts for example).

documentation.short: Clears the flag for the given index.
documentation.long: Clears the flag for the given index. The flag is automatically cleared after the Neighborhood.evicted event is fired.

documentation.short: Clears the flag for all indices
Returns the value of the flag for the given index
Sets the flag for the given index
Every component maintains its own neighborhood data.
documentation.long: Every component maintains its own neighborhood data. The Neighboorhood component maintains only the nodeids and ages of the neighbors, and evicts old entries from the table when necessary.

documentation.short: Returns the age of the given entry.
documentation.long: Returns the age of the given entry. The age is incremented by one every time a new node is inserted into the neighborhood table that is not already at the very end. If the age would get too large to fit into a byte, then it is periodically reset to a smaller value.

documentation.short: Adds a new node into the neighborhood table.
documentation.long: Adds a new node into the neighborhood table. If this node was already in the table, then it is just brought to the front (its age is reset to zero). If the node was not in the table, then the oldest is evicted and its entry is replaced with this node. The index of the entry is returned in the range [0, NEIGHBORHOOD-1].

documentation.short: Returns the node address for the given entry.
documentation.long: Returns the node address for the given entry.

documentation.short: This event is fired when the oldest entry is replaced with a new node.
documentation.long: This event is fired when the oldest entry is replaced with a new node. The same interface is used by many users, so all of them will receive this event and can clear the corresponding entry. After this event is fired, all flags for this entry are cleared (see the NeighborhoodFlag interface)

documentation.short: Returns the index of the neighbor in the table.
documentation.long: Returns the index of the neighbor in the table. If the node was not found in the table, then the value NEIGHBORHOOD is returned, otherwise an index in the range [0, NEIGHBORHOOD-1] is returned.

documentation.short: Signals the completion of the clear channel assesment send command.
documentation.long: Signals the completion of the clear channel assesment send command. SUCCESS means the channel is clear, EBUSY means the channel is not clear, and FAIL means that the clear channel assesment could not be finished or the operation was cancelled.

documentation.short: Starts the clear channel assesment procedure.
documentation.long: Starts the clear channel assesment procedure. Returns EBUSY if the radio is currently servicing a clear channel assesment, and SUCCESS otherwise. The check will be performed only in the RX_READY state.

documentation.short: Starts the transmission of the given message.
documentation.long: Starts the transmission of the given message. This command must not be called while another send is in progress (so one must wait for the sendDone event). Returns EBUSY if a reception is in progress or for some other reason the request cannot be temporarily satisfied (e.g. the SPI bus access could not be acquired). In this case the send command could be retried from a tasklet. Returns SUCCESS if the transmission could be started. In this case sendDone will be fired.

documentation.short: This event is fired when the component is most likely able to accept a send request.
documentation.long: This event is fired when the component is most likely able to accept a send request. If the send command has returned with a failure, then this event will be called at least once in the near future.

documentation.short: Signals the completion of the send command, exactly once for each successfull send command.
documentation.long: Signals the completion of the send command, exactly once for each successfull send command. If the returned error code is SUCCESS, then the message was sent (may not have been acknowledged), otherwise the message was not transmitted over the air.

documentation.short: Moves to radio into sleep state with the lowest power consumption but highest wakeup time.
documentation.long: Moves to radio into sleep state with the lowest power consumption but highest wakeup time. The radio cannot send or receive in this state and releases all access to shared resources (e.g. SPI bus).

documentation.short: Goes into receive state.
documentation.long: Goes into receive state. The radio continuously receive messages and able to transmit.

documentation.short: Sets the current channel.
documentation.long: Sets the current channel. Returns EBUSY if the stack is unable to change the channel this time (some other operation is in progress) SUCCESS otherwise.

documentation.short: This event is signaled exactly once for each successfully posted state transition and setChannel command when it is completed.
documentation.long: This event is signaled exactly once for each successfully posted state transition and setChannel command when it is completed.

documentation.short: The same as the turnOff command, except it is not as deep sleep, and it is quicker to recover from this state.
documentation.long: The same as the turnOff command, except it is not as deep sleep, and it is quicker to recover from this state.

documentation.short: Returns the currently selected channel.
documentation.long: Returns the currently selected channel.

documentation.short: Interface for generating 16-bit and 32-bit random numbers.
Produces a 32-bit pseudorandom number.
documentation.long: Produces a 32-bit pseudorandom number. @return Returns low 16 bits of the pseudorandom number.

documentation.short: Produces a 32-bit pseudorandom number.
documentation.long: Produces a 32-bit pseudorandom number. @return Returns the 32-bit pseudorandom number.

documentation.short: Initialize this component.
Sets the flag in this message to FALSE
Returns if the flag is set for this message.
documentation.long: Returns if the flag is set for this message.

documentation.short: Sets the flag in this message to the specified value.
documentation.long: Sets the flag in this message to the specified value.

documentation.short: Sets the flag in this message to TRUE
